title: So Many Solo Queue Threads
body: Some of them are polite, some of them are hella rude, but they all share one thing in common - no Riot responses. Feels bad man.

X people make " WE WANT SOLOQUE Q___Q" threads, obviously riot wont answer all of them because they already explained their thoughts about the topic.

Which red posts are you talking about? There was the one stickied post where they mostly talked about what they wanted to do in dynamic queue, and then mentioned oh by the way there's the possibility solo queue will never come out. Yeah, Dynamic Queue is so glorified that your ranks prior to Dynamic Queue's existence actually means the world.
/s

News flash: They don't, for at least 2 reasons. First of all, it doesn't matter what ranks you are in if you aren't playing for anything higher than Masters. Oh do you really think your shiny little Platinum- borders mean anything more than elo stroking?

Second, your ranks are never the correct indicators of your MMR unless you play at least 500-1000 ranked games per season. Sure winning games gets your LP but the LP you gain does not represent your hidden MMR, because you can suck and get carried in a match and still win. It doesn't mean anything unless you play a large amount of games and have large sample sizes. Many of you don't play that much and thus it's pointless to talk about the _oh-so-holy_ accuracy of your ranks. You really think I should take your less-than-500-ranked-games ranks seriously and compare them to people who actually invest at least their time equal to at least 500 games in ranked?

Last but not least, this game is a team game. Measuring individual performance in a team game is very difficult, and Riot has not proven that they have a set of good criteria measuring individual effort in a team game that doesn't break something or allow the abuse of something. So again, the LP and the ranks you gain means jackshit if you don't play more than 500 ranked games, which a majority of you cannot fulfill in the slightest. Ironically speaking, asking a group of strangers to cooperate in a team game just doesn't make a whole lot of sense. No other sports apart from Esports in terms of professional scenes require a player to get randomly assigned to a group of players to play a team match collectively, and and measure individual performances instead of the performance as a whole for the final result of the match.

I know the execution of Dynamic Queue is flawed and there is a lot more work needed to be done to fix the problems at hand but acting as if the previous system is accurate and functional is actually a joke. Just because you and a bunch of people dislike the idea of Dynamic Queue doesn't make it any less of a good idea.

You know what makes a playerbase smaller? A competitive community so intent on proving themselves they become toxic to any one who  so much as misses CS in lane because it might cost them the chance at a shiny border.

Also, I disagree with your statement that premades shouldn't be a golden ticket, being able to communicate with your teammates should give you an advantage in a team based game. Hell, that's why we have the LCS. If you want to prove your skill on a personal level, play a shooter or a game that doesn't require you to team up with other players. If mechanics were everything a lot of players I know in bronze and silver would be a division higher than they are now. But surprise surprise, being able to play Katarina perfectly means nothing if your team does jack diddly squat to set you up for the pentakills.

With a premade you can spend days, or weeks perfecting a premade. In solo queue, you get a few seconds, assuming everyone cooperates and communicates. 

Know what else makes a community smaller? When bots run rampant in certain servers, balance becomes messy, the company starts hiding information from the playerbase, and doesn't listen to the playerbase.

The ranks are used to show individual skill. If you want to show your skill in creating your own Pro LoL 5 man group or whatever, play the 5man ranked queue. 

Yes, we have the LCS, made up of organized groups who practice together and meet often, of course they'd tear up the ladder in ranked, they'll stomp on all the solo queues. So what, you want to punish every other challenger player they go against for not being part of LCS? Ok.

With DQ I can at least try help my friends just learn how to not tilt and talk them through winning a ranked game so they can at least finish placements.

Implying I have 5 friends available at all times. The ranks are there to show how adaptable you are in a team. Having challenger level mechanics means nothing in a 1v5 situation if your team just runs off.

And to take away from that natural adverting would be denying the game an important aspect of playing it (communicating with your team mates). You can solo the ladder, but in a team game individual skill is only worth so much. 

**Solo queue isn't punished. It simply does not have advantages. There's a difference between getting punished and not having advantages. I can try finish a 4-man project on my own, but I'm not getting punished because I chose not to get a team together and finish the project, I simply don't have the advantages having a team gives me.**

You can try, but it probably won't happen, everyone will want to do their own thing, and there is rarely communication. You can't reasonably do it. In game, you have more communication. You don't deal with trolls of AFKs. You won't have the devourer jgler farming 24/7 and never ganking. You pull cheese comboes. Teamfights are organized etc.

Your point? Ranked is supposed to be competitive. What's the point of "ranked" if it's used for casuals. People who solely play normals and then goof off in ranked, saying "it's just a game" are causing toxicity. You can chill in a game, but you can't pull a Kaceytron.

I'm not implying you have 5 friends at all times. Some people do that. A lot of them, just like Elo boosters. 2 is already a huge advantage, 3 and above is even more powerful.

Ranks are used to show how good you are as a player, not adaptability. It's about consistent individual skill, while Ranked 5v5s are to show how well you work as a team.

> Solo queue isn't punished. It simply does not have advantages. There's a difference between getting punished and not having advantages. I can try finish a 4-man project on my own, but I'm not getting punished because I chose not to get a team together and finish the project, I simply don't have the advantages having a team gives me.

You shouldn't have ridiculous advantages like that. Premades should not be able to troll/bully the solo queue players. Premades should not have so many ingame advantages.

Just look at any of the anti solo queue posts, a ton of them have been popping up on the front page.

1. You have 2 whole minutes to talk to the randos in your game before you play. Use that time. If you don't, don't be surprised when your team has no synergy.

2. I'm fine with competitiveness. What I'm not fine is if it brings out the absolute worst in everyone. You can be competitive and still be a good sport, although it seems that concept is a foreign notion here in League.

3. Individual skill meaning champion mechanical skill? Because mechanics don't get you very far in League. Knowing how to work around a team you just met (how to adapt to the team) is a much more valuable skill. Heck, a lot of guides I've read on SummonerSchool don't tell you to play to your level, but to play to your team's level, because your mechanical skill means nothing if your team can't follow up.

4. I'm sorry if every premade you've been in has "trolled" you, but every premade I've been in Ranked has been the most try hard group of league players I've ever faced or played with. I don't call working together flawlessly trolling, I call that really good teamwork. 

5. Premades by their nature have an advantage over solo players in a TEAM game. Complaining about how premades are unfair in League is like complaining how unfair it is for a couple to have a relationship. In a team game, the team that has the best communication is the one that wins. It's harder to pull off when you're not talking, but I've pulled randos together and pinged/chat'd until everyone was on the same page.

1. Me: Hey, can you guys tell what champs you guys are playing via pick intent?
Them: Silence.

I ALWAYS try to communicate; They never do anything. Of course it's just the silent premade bot who'll pick a TF ADC and Zed support, or some ridiculous thing like that without talking

2. It's not competitiveness, it's other people being toxic to each other, and people being unable to truly retaliate leads to brewing resentment and more toxicity. It's not only competitiveness. That is just one of the things. Being a good person is not only rare to see in LoL and other video games, but everywhere on the internet these days. It's a problem we try to prevent, but it doesn't work, and efforts to do so often lead to more toxicity.

3. Individual skill means mechanical skill, willingness to cooperate with complete strangers , consistency in said features, perserverence, etc. Going premade doesn't let you create now bonds and show teamwork with different strangers. Going premade just keeps the same bonds, makes you just spam the same cheese stratagies, creating unpleasant experiences for enemy teams (feeling cheated), allies (lack of communication from premade going on skype/Curse), or the premade bullying the solo queuers

They can troll you to death, or they can go full Tryhard, copy a LCS team, and rek you. That's not the teamwork (communicating with strangers and working with them for limited time) that should be applied for solo queue

Of course you win games with communication through randoms. But you often communicate very little, or they ignore you. This is a bit misleading. It would only increase queue times for dynamic queue. Solo queue would have significantly faster queue times. Dynamic queue would really die outside of the 5 man pre-mades (aka the old team ranked system but more than a 9 man per team limit so improvement). The reality of the situation is solo queue would solve the major ranked problems, it would just kill off their ever so precious 2 to 4 man pre-made (especially the 4 man premades) dynamic queues that obviously fails the "what the players want most" test.

Can you explain the logic behind that?  Because it doesn't make sense to me.

Suppose right now (in dynamic queue) you have ten players (of equal MMR) all queuing.  Two are an ADC+Supp duo, while the others are all single players.
That is one game right there, and it can instantly create a lobby.

However, if the same ten players queue up in the separate queues (the duo going into the dynamic queue, the eight solo players going into the solo queue), then there aren't enough matching players to make a game.

I can't see any situation where finding a game would be slower *for the solo players* in dynamic queue.  The matchmaker should try to pit roughly-equal-sized teams of players together, and then fill the remaining spaces with solo players (or smaller teams that still fit.)

If it's doing something other than that, then it's a fault with the matchmaking algorithm that they should fix.


To put that another way:  If you split the queues, if 70% of the players join soloQ and 30% of the players join the new team queue, then it will take roughly 43% longer to find solo games and roughly 333% longer to find team games - in other words, longer queue times for everyone involved.

The problem is that there aren't 100 players (of equal MMR) queueing up for a game at the same time, or you would always find games instantly.
The number of people playing the game at any given time is incredibly high, yes, but not high enough that there are always 100 players *of equal MMR* in the queue at the same time.

The matchmaker should be trying to fill a game with 10 players of roughly-equal MMR, working to fill the required slots in any way that it can with the currently-available players.

How quickly it can find a match is based on the rate at which appropriate players join the queue.  The time it takes for two players of equal MMR to queue up for each role and get matched to the two opposing teams.

Splitting the queues *reduces the rate at which players enter each queue*.
If there are less players queueing up at any given time, then of course it's going to take longer for the matchmaker to find 20 appropriate players to put into a game together.

Yes, the time increase will be significantly lower than the increase for dynamic queue, but it will certainly still be there.


For example, the following players enter the queue (all at equal MMR, or average MMR for teams)
00:00 mid
00:10 top
00:11 mid
00:12 top
00:14 adc+supp duo
00:15 adc
00:16 mid
00:17 jungle
00:18 top
00:19 jungle
00:25 supp
00:30 mid
00:31 adc
00:32 top
00:38 jungle
00:40 supp

In this example, the first point at which there are enough players to fill every role twice is at 25 seconds.  At that point, there are (at least) two of each role in the queue, and a game can be formed.

However, if you split the queues, the adc+supp duo who joined at 00:14 will not be added to this queue, so instead the matchmaker has to wait for 40 seconds to build a game, because that's the earliest point when there are two players for each role.

And in that example, only 2/17 players are joining as a team - the actual number would probably be higher.
